But you know, there's nothing we could have done to avoid this. Americans don't save. Un-American.

Where can I get a safe 5% per year return on my savings?

And by "return" I mean "real return", i.e. after inflation. It has to go up every year to allow for price increases, especially in things like food and heating that aren't included in the official comsumer price index. I don't plan to buy many iPads and iPhones in my twilight years, but I will need to eat and keep warm.

Where can we get a low-risk 5% return on our investments? If you tell us, we will hurry to get some, their price will go up, and the return will go down, while the value of your 5% investments will rise.

It does not look good for those who plan to continue working, either, since jobs are scarce these days.

I see a retirement disaster coming. Social Security is just enough to keep you out of the soup line, but it does not provide much of a living beyond that. Corporations have managed to weasel out of traditional defined benefit pension plans and replace them with defined contribution plans and 401K plans, non of which provide the kind of income the older plans did. Along with that they have discontinued retirees medical plans.

Worse yet a great many of those about to retire have lost the equity in their homes. Equity that they planned on using to buy less expensive homes in retirement communities, mostly in the sun belt. Those towns such as Surprise Arizona are already feeling the loss. The RV industry, the cruise industry, the travel industry are already seeing the lack of retirees discretionary income.

I see the figure of $120K for these about to retire households. At 5% that is only $6K a year, add that to the SS and if two people are each getting $16K that adds up to $38K a year for those households, and that assumes they do not have a high debt level.

This does not look good for those planning on retiring in the near future.

Since I'm living in London now, I also had the good fortune to be a Games Maker who volunteered for the 2012 Olympics and Paralympics. I couldn't agree more that the way the Paralympics were embraced in Britain was absolutely fantastic.

But I think the rather harsh tone in many quarters about coverage in the US compared to the UK is a bit unfair. After all, the Paralympics were on the doorstep of much of Britain's population. If the Paralympics had been held in New York, I'm sure that the NY Times and other US media would have provided considerably more coverage than they did (even if not to this year's impressive British standard). What's more, from what I can see, Paralympics coverage was very uneven in many other countries around the world.

Fortunately, London 2012 has raised the Paralympics profile hugely. So I'm very optimistic that the coverage of the 2016 Rio Games will improve dramatically in the US and elsewhere (probably also helped by the much smaller time difference between Rio and most of the US). And, of course, let's not forget the 2014 Winter Paralympics in Sochi!

Last time the Steelers saw these Jets, they were scared to death that they were one mistake from blowing a 24-0 halftime lead for the right to go to the Super Bowl. The time before that, the Jets took home a win. In other words, the Steelers know that these Jets come to town looking to match up and take it to them.

One would expect the Jets offense to take the field planning to succeed. A week of familiarity under game conditions, things they can certainly improve, the WIldcat yet to truly unfold. If there is one thing the Jets offense can accomplish this year, it will be to throw things at their opponent for which there is very little tape. The Steelers will be dealing with formations and plays that nobody has seen yet.

As for the Jets defense: Ever since that first half pasting in the last meeting, this defense has struggled to live up to its reputation for meeting a challenge head on and holding their own. There have been holes, especially on the ground, and trouble getting off the field, and trouble holding a lead, and trouble pressuring the opposing quarterback. Week one against the Bills is certainly an incomplete. Up 41-7, let them get too close for comfort. Can they stop the run yet?

The Steelers need this win, their home opener, to avoid going 0-2 to start the season. It is tempting to pick the Jets, and certainly a win is within their grasp if the offense continues to click. My gut tells me the Jets fight hard but the Steelers wear them down in the end, 27 - 23.

I think discussion of tax cuts and economic growth is confounded by many other variables, most notably energy costs. Reagan's tax cut may appear to have produced great economic growth if you ignore the fact that energy costs declined about 40% during his administration. Energy costs remained low during Clinton's term but then increased substantially during the Bush 43 presidency. I wrote about it here: http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/ten-miles-square/2012/05/like_president...

The reduction in energy costs during the Reagan Administration was two to three times the value of reductions in federal tax revenues. The increase in energy expenditures during Bush's administration was about the same magnitude as the reduction in federal revenues.

In 2008, imports of fossil fuels to the US cost nearly 3% of GDP, which was greater than the previous record high of 2.5% of GDP in 1980.

Energy makes the industrial world go around.

For the newcomers to the global enterprise it would be nice to have some do's and don'ts spelled out for their businesses not unlike what the State department or Foreign Service staff are exposed to before they set foot in a new country.

Let us see who cares about the poor farmers and the small traders.

It is the middlemen who make the greatest profit and they are the biggest contributors to the political parties. The middlemen, with the backing of the political parties (means muscle power), keeps the procurement price low and the market price high (often 2-4 times high). There is a point in talking about the "poor farmers" but also an equally important point in keeping them "poor".

We have already hundreds of supermarkets here and they have not affected the "pop and mom" kirana stores. Most pop and mom kirana shops run on credit (mostly) and charge high. Only people who can pay cash goes to the supermarket. The clients of the corner shops are not going to be lost.

One of these "pop and mom" store owners was telling me the other day the "taxes" he has to pay to keep his business. These taxes go to the local unemployed men, affliated to some political party, and he just keeps a "small" cut.

Well, I think Wallmark (and others) will be bypassing these "boys" and deal directly with the "boss". That is the rub.

Some low end enployment will surely be generated. I do not see any impact on other "small stores"- they will run as usual and nothing will change (not much anyway).

People like me who pay cash and get small things will certainly welcome walmart. In china, walmart pays too low salary (to their employees) and I hope they will pay a little bit better here.
